image.altText: A rainbow flag waving outside of Parliament House.

props.synopsis: The NT government has walked back on its plans to scrap hate speech protections in the territory's anti-discrimination laws. However there are still fears the changes will "water down" laws against vilification.

title.children: NT government accused of 'watering down' anti-discrimination laws

image.altText: A politician with blonde hair, wearing glasses.

props.synopsis: The NT attorney-general has revealed a $300,000 racism review into the NT Police Force has been scrapped, with the funding redirected to Legal Aid.

title.children: NT police racism review scrapped, funding redirected

image.altText: A Timor-Leste player kicking a soccer ball onto the field.

props.synopsis: Timor-Leste representatives say the national soccer team's victory in an Asian Cup qualifier in Darwin isn't just about boosting its chances in the competition, but is also a powerful showcase of culture and community.

title.children: Soccer strengthening cultural ties as Top End hosts Timor-Leste

image.altText: Alexander's daughter in the snow

props.synopsis: While the weather might be drastically different in Tasmania and the NT during winter, the social calendar is equally busy.

title.children: The magic of winter in Tasmania, and the 'chill' in Darwin

image.altText: A person hauls nets and marine debris buried underneath the white sand at a beach in Arnhem Land

props.synopsis: It's rubbish season in northern Australia, when tonnes of plastic and discarded fishing nets wash ashore in the Gulf of Carpentaria. But the future of funding for clean-up patrols is unclear.

title.children: Gulf ghost-net patrols fear tide turning in fight to save remote beaches

image.altText: Plasma donor at Australian Red Cross Blood Service

props.synopsis: Restrictions around sexually active gay and bisexual men donating blood and plasma are being loosened in a new world-leading move by Australian Red Cross Lifeblood.

title.children: World-leading changes to sexual activity rules for blood, plasma donating

image.altText: a crude oil tanker sails away from the camera in foggy murky waters

props.synopsis: The government says "Russia uses these vessels to circumvent international sanctions and sustain its illegal and immoral war against Ukraine".

title.children: Australia hits Russia's 'deceptive' shadow fleet with sanctions

image.altText: A close-up of Jim Chalmers in front of a grey background

props.synopsis: Defence Minister Richard Marles says he is "sure" the prime minister will meet face-to-face with the US president in the "not so distant future". Follow live.

title.children: Chalmers open to 'fresh' tax reforms, foresees 'trade off' for some

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: PM considering trip to NATO summit
'We're mature about that': PM on cancelled Trump meeting
Albanese raised tariffs and critical minerals with US officials

image.altText: Billy Slater talks to media

props.synopsis: Queensland coach Billy Slater apologises for bringing up Paul Green's death in a snap press conference just hours out from Origin II in Perth.

title.children: Billy Slater 'deeply and genuinely sorry' for Paul Green reference in emotional presser

image.altText: A worker wearing a hard hat with the CFMEU logo emblazoned across it.

props.synopsis: Former CFMEU officials lose a High Court challenge to changes to the Fair Work Act which forced the construction arm of the union into administration.

title.children: Former CFMEU officials fail to overturn federal government takeover

image.altText: large, orange mushroom cloud takes up the evening sky over a woman standing outside her house

props.synopsis: One of Indonesia's most active volcanoes has erupted, spewing hot ash and smoke plumes seen 150 kilometres away.

title.children: 'Quite large': Indonesian volcano erupts, spewing hot ash into mushroom cloud

image.altText: A man in a royal blue suit, white shirt and light blue tie sits in a room with red carpet looking toward something out of frame

props.synopsis: General He Weidong, China's second-ranking military official and a co-vice-chairman of the powerful Central Military Commission, has not been seen in public since March.

title.children: Beijing's inner circle fractures as Xi's top military official disappears

image.altText: A smiling woman sits with her laughing daughter on her lap.

props.synopsis: A Sydney mother is calling for change after being told her daughter with disability would have to wait five months for a scan her doctor said was urgent.

title.children: 5yo girl with growth in ear told to wait five months for scan

image.altText: Next ATM in a closed tobacconist in Burpengary

props.synopsis: An ABC investigation finds that among investments raking in the dollars for the Australian-founded Macquarie Group is the nation's billion-dollar illegal tobacco trade.

title.children: Macquarie Group-backed private ATMs are helping fuel the illegal tobacco trade

image.altText: A man being led by multiple police officers into the back of a paddy wagon.

props.synopsis: The four males have been charged with multiple offences including aggravated sexual assault and sexual intercourse without consent, with two expected to appear in court on Wednesday.

title.children: Alleged gang rape of 17yo girl in Sydney 'will affect her life forever'

image.altText: a flat triangle shaped black plane flies high over an airbase

props.synopsis: It is thought bunker-buster bombs — the kind only possessed by the United States — are required to significantly damage Iran's key Fordow nuclear fuel enrichment plant.

title.children: Why Israel can't destroy Iran's nuclear site under a mountain on its own

image.altText: A large fireball rises into the sky at night as people watch on from a nearby bridge

props.synopsis: The ASX has opened lower after Donald Trump said the US would not kill Iran's supreme leader 'for now', while the Australian dollar fell below 65 US cents and oil prices surged again. Follow live.

title.children: Stocks fall as Trump's threats against Iran send oil prices surging

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Treasurer delivers key National Press Club address to set out second term agenda
Optus CEO Stephen Rue responds to ACCC announcement

image.altText: HMAS Toowoomba

props.synopsis: The PM rules out deploying Australian naval assets to the Middle East even as European leaders mull support for a possible US intervention.

title.children: PM rules out deploying Australian naval assets to Middle East

image.altText: Two men in suits walking from the right of frame to left.

props.synopsis: A magistrate finds the prosecution had not proven "beyond reasonable doubt" that the police officer used a restricted QPS database to track the whereabouts of his former partner.

title.children: Police officer found not guilty of using database to track former partner

image.altText: Santos's Darwin LNG plant is seen from overhead at dusk.

props.synopsis: Cash offer to Santos from the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company is understood to be the richest in history. But some are unconvinced the deal will proceed.

title.children: Has the Santos takeover handed the government a gift on energy security?

image.altText: Kate Robinson

props.synopsis: Kate Robinson left her laptop on charge in her bedroom while running errands. An hour later, she returned to find her house and yoga studio engulfed in flames.

title.children: 'Flames on my bed': Warning after fire caused by charging laptop guts home

image.altText: A man wearing a biege button-up shirt looks at a computer screen while seated inside.

props.synopsis: Writer Alistair Kitchen said he was refused entry to the US last week after being grilled about his views on the Gaza conflict and articles he wrote about pro-Palestinian protests.

title.children: Australian turned away from border for drug use, US government says

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith wearing a blue shirt and white shirt with a tie

props.synopsis: Veteran Ben Roberts-Smith takes his legal battle with Nine Newspapers to the High Court.

title.children: 'A condemnation of the most ruinous kind': Ben Roberts-Smith appeals to High Court

image.altText: A womans hands pointing at an old black and white photo in a book.

props.synopsis: There are fears for thousands of photos and archives held in the Sisters of St John of God Heritage Centre Broome that are not protected by law.

title.children: Families plead to protect Stolen Generations records as centre closes

image.altText: Lord Mayor Adrian Schrinner speaks into microphones

props.synopsis: Brisbane City Council has handed down a high-tax but low-spending budget while accusing the state and federal governments of "cost shifting" onto local councils.

title.children: Brisbane City Council unveils high-tax but low-spending budget

image.altText: A graphic imge of a farmer looking at sheep.

props.synopsis: Mental health experts warn of the dangers of spreading misinformation after unverified figures of the number of Victorian farmers who have taken their own lives circulated on social media.

title.children: Warning for MPs over 'dangerous' mental health misinformation

image.altText: A woman in profile looks pensive

props.synopsis: One of the largest local Aboriginal land councils in NSW has initiated a review into its governance as it battles allegations of nepotism and intimidation.

title.children: Land council board member quits, goes to police after heated meeting

image.altText: Dakota Johnson sits at a table in a white top. Pedro Pascal leans seductively into her shoulder, Chris Evans stares longingly

props.synopsis: Materialists may star Hollywood heart-throbs, but it's not quite what it appears. Director Celine Song talks about making a rom-com that shows the reality of modern dating.

title.children: It may look like a rom-com, but Materialists is not a first-date movie

image.altText: a giant loader dumps red ore into an equally large dumptruck as seen from an aerial perspective

props.synopsis: Australia's biggest customer for iron ore doesn't need as much steel anymore, but the Pilbara's biggest producers have no plans to slow down production.

title.children: Iron ore is Australia's most valuable export, but China's data suggests that's changing

image.altText: a group walk along a country road in Western Victoria bounded by dry paddocks

props.synopsis: A Yoorrook Justice Commissioner is set to reach Victorian parliament after walking 500 kilometres to mark the closure of Australia’s first formal Aboriginal truth-telling inquiry.

title.children: Thousands join walk as Australian-first truth-telling inquiry ends

image.altText: Several seals laying on a shelf of ice in Antarctica.

props.synopsis: Australia's ability to conduct strategic, in-depth, and long-term research in Antarctica is being compromised by "terminating" funding models for key programs, scientists warn.

title.children: Antarctic research jeopardised by 'terminating' funding, scientists say

image.altText: Three men wearing hi-vis and hard hats, one of them speaks at microphone

props.synopsis: The federal energy minister will announce changes to how benchmark power prices are set, aimed at cutting back how much energy retailers can hit consumers to cover costs like advertising, on Wednesday.

title.children: Federal government to change power price rules to push costs lower

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair wearing a denim top holding a teddy

props.synopsis: Newborn baby Alby died after an obstructed labour. Despite an initial coroner's report ruling his death was not preventable, a fresh investigation has been launched.

title.children: Inquest for newborn baby boy who died in Queensland hospital

image.altText: A rock carving of an emu on red rocks

props.synopsis: After UNESCO expressed concern that the extension of Woodside's North West Shelf gas facility would cause nearby Murujuga rock art to be rejected from the World Heritage List, the environment minister will dispatch officials to lobby the agency to reconsider.

title.children: Government to protest UNESCO concerns for Murujuga rock art in Paris

image.altText: Pint being poured

props.synopsis: The ongoing US-China trade war sparks an opportunity for breweries like WA's Rocky Ridge and Shelter Brewing to make their first forays into the Asian giant.

title.children: Craft brewer says beer easier to sell in Beijing than Busselton
